etymologies: late Middle English (denoting the action of returning to or from a place): from Old French, or from Latin reversio(n-), from revertere ‘turn back’ (see reverse)

definitions: a return to a previous state, practice, or belief

examples.text: there was some reversion to polytheism
a reversion to the two-party system

shortDefinitions: return to previous state or belief

definitions: the action of reverting to a former or ancestral type

examples.text: a problem applicable to most variegated plants is that of reversion

shortDefinitions: action of reverting to former or ancestral type

definitions: the right, especially of the original owner or their heirs, to possess or succeed to property on the death of the present possessor or at the end of a lease
a property to which someone has the right of reversion

examples.text: parties buying and selling leases and reversions

shortDefinitions: property to which someone has right of reversion

definitions: the right of succession to an office or post after the death or retirement of the holder

examples.text: he was given a promise of the reversion of Boraston's job

shortDefinitions: right of succession to office or post after death or retirement of holder
